trial_identification.studytitle: Evaluation of a public health intervention to reduce alcohol consumption among pregnant women.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Pregnant women receiving a public health education booklet compared to a control group receiving standard antenatal care to assess improvements in knowledge on the issue of alcohol consumption during pregnancy.

interventions.interventions: Educational information package providing recipes for non-alcoholic mocktails as well as facts about the harms of alcohol consumption in pregnancy, links to further support, and advice on how to cut back. The information package is in the form of a booklet handed out at antenatal appointments. The booklet will be handed out at baseline only.
interventions.comparator: Standard antenatal care from midwives, shared care GPs, or obstetricians.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Knowledge as assessed by percentage of correct answers to 13 true/false statements in "Alcohol use in pregnancy" questionnaire. This questionnaire has been designed specifically for this study, and is based on previous similar questionnaires. It has been tested for validity and reliability.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and at four weeks after birth (approximately 24 weeks after intervention commencement)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Attitude towards alcohol use in pregnancy as assessed by 8 statements measured on a likert scale ranging from strongly disagree to strongly agree.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and four weeks after birth (approximately 24 weeks after intervention commencement)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Alcohol consumption rates as measured by questions taken from the National Drug Strategy Household Survey concerning quantity of alcohol consumed in last 12 months, types of alcohol consumed, and regularity of drinking sessions.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and four weeks after birth (approximately 24 weeks after intervention commencement)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Participants over 18 years of age. Women receiving antenatal care at the WCH. Women with a gestational age between 16 and 24 weeks. Women who have consumed alcohol at some stage in the past. Participants who agree to be followed up post-delivery to complete a questionnaire.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Participants unable to comprehend English. Participants with a current substance abuse problem. Participants with severe, uncontrolled mental illness. Participants with cognitive impairment that could interfere with their ability to consent. Participants who consider themselves non-drinkers.

recruitment.hospital: Womens and Childrens Hospital - North Adelaide

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: School of Nursing and Midwifery Centenary Building Room C5-48 UniSA City East campus Frome Road Adelaide SA 5001

fundingsource.fundingaddress: UniSA City East campus Frome Road Adelaide SA 5001

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: School of Nursing and Midwifery Centenary building Room C4-28 UniSA City East campus Frome Rd Adelaide SA 5001

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Evaluation of a newly developed educational information package which provides information on alchol consumption during pregnancy, links to support, and alternatives to drinking for pregnant women. Study hypothesis states that the intervention will improve knowledge about the effects of alcohol consumption during pregnancy significantly more than standard antenatal care.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Women's and Children's Health Network HREC
